comment: Not much of a bourbon drinker, but I found this to be very smooth. Sweet, yet not as syrupy as Jack Daniels. It does finish quick and clean. Because I find that it doesn't linger as long on the tongue as others, the time between sips is shorter.
Add a dash of water and pour and let breathe only pour one finger at a time
A bit too expensive for what it is (in Canada). Drink with a dash of water to get full taste
This was a very good bourbon style whiskey. A little hotter than it needed to be. But a dash of water fixed that.
this has a lingering warmth but overall a well rounded flavor. I would purchase again.
Smooth, almost creamy. Strong caramel, vanilla, butterscotch, a little died fruits. Balanced full flavor.

Tasted 12/17/2014 :  Corn sweetness backed with the spicey rye-ness when nosing.  A nice, creamy, full palate. Finishes quickly leaving black pepper spice with mild tongue burn.  The creamy body, mild spice and sweetness on the nose all combine to make a very enjoyable dram.  Good neat or a splash. Rather enjoyed the sugar and spice.
Not tremendously flavorful but certainly a subtle sweetness with some fruit and spice.

High West American Prairie Reserve isn't a bad whiskey--it's pretty good, actually. It's just hurt by the fact that it's more expensive than it should be. To wit: one of its component whiskeys comes from Four Roses, but I can buy a bottle of Four Roses Single Barrel for $10-15 less locally. And in terms of flavours, this is a blend whose lineage is unmistakeably a mix of LDI and Four Roses: the gin-y, herbal, metholated, faintly nutty character of LDI whiskey with the cherry cola and plums of Four Roses. And yet it tastes strangely younger than its age--surprisingly green and hot. Flavours here of clove, caraway, mint, vanilla, fruit, baking spice. Chocolate, cinnamon, some orange peel. A lot of sweetness with a spice backbone on the taste. Good whiskey, and I suppose you can feel good about some of the proceeds going to charity, but I really would just rather pay less for the superior tasting, higher ABV Four Roses Single Barrel.
Very spicy, a little sweet. Unbalanced and needs to be mellowed out with more aging.
Charcoal, cloves, black pepper, leather, dried cherries. Good flavors, not the best finish. Still a solid bourbon for the price. [84]
The faint spice hits me most, followed by light citrus. Quick finish. Ok if my favorites aren't around.

Not my favorite outing from high west but as usual, much better than most efforts. Sipping neat it has an interesting finish. Not the complexity I come to expect from Dave and team. This would be a perfect whiskey for cocktails.
I love this whiskey in an old fashion. Just the right amount of spice. I've been meaning to get a bottle for the house.
Sweet with a heavy note upfront with a smoothe finish. $38 for the bottle and recommend for s good sipping whiskey
Beaucoup trop vanillé à mon goût. Désolé
Not as good as their eyes, better than the silver. On the spicy side, cinnamon and clove and tobacco (?). Would make a killer cocktail
Rather impressed with this whiskey. Great nose with a bit of butteriness. Taste was smooth and sweet. Great whiskey for the price.
Tastes a bit more peppery and harsh on the nose.  Blend of a couple of different bourbons (including 4roses from what I read)
crazy light with a woody arfter taste (not smokey) yummy

Nose: corn, butter, very sweet smooth
Taste: Smooth, sweet, and fruity. No aclool taste at all.
Finish: medium  burn
One of favorite go-to bourbons. A nice blend with a decent price mark.

Definitely got some of the same notes I get from Four Roses Small Batch, so there must be some rye in the bourbon mashbill. It was too hot, a little water helped tame it but still has some rough edges

Another bourbon where I'm completely off the Distiller notes -- I wonder if I was having a weird taste day yesterday.  The nose almost seems sherried to me, as the strongest scents I got were raisins, dates, and figs.  Relative to the average bourbon, Prairie Reserve has a spicier nose.  The palate also struck me as spicier than average (and after looking it up online, I've seen some sites reporting that one of the bourbons in the mix is Four Roses, which would make sense given that distillery's high-rye mashbills).  The classic bourbon flavors are also there, along with a bit of Cherry Coca Cola.  The finish, consistent with the palate and nose, is peppery; that sherry sensation returns, and then it mellows out to an herbal and slightly bitter grassiness.  Since the flavor profile hits so many of the same spice notes as Four Roses, and the superlative Four Roses Single Barrel is around the same price, I'd recommend just going straight to the source.
A good bourbon for the price. Very creamy and buttery with some spice to it. Has a medium finish with some heat.

Solo: delicious complex first taste but incredibly bitter after taste
Fried foods: first taste remains and the bitterness is smoothed out. Pretty good with fried food!
Nose - Candy corn, walnuts, vanilla, dried fruit. Taste - Candy corn, vanilla, very light oak.
Smooth, goes down easy. Nice subtle flavoring. For $36 it fits he bill. I'll stock this at home for that price
Classic bourbon with dill and oak
Boring bourbon.  Save your money.  Buffalo Trace is cheaper and better by miles.
Very simple flavors, and they don’t last very long. The marketing on this one is clear, “Maple syrup and caramel, then I’m out”.
Good bourbon blend, through and through.
A very nice and mellow bourbon with notes of fruit and spices up front.  Really well over a whiskey rock, no burn.

Another Drinks by the Dram Sample. My second after a long break...

Nose: Barrel spices, oak, baking spice (nutmeg and clove), and vanilla. 

Palate:  nice coating mouthfeel. Good balance of sweet and spice.  

Finish:  short and a bit hot.  

Not a bad dram, but I’m unlikely to pull a muscle seeking it out. 3 solid stars.
Not incredibly smooth but I love the bite and varying spice with each sip. Drank neat at room temp. Not a bad whiskey.
Mostly, i prefer bourbon. This is a good wood forward expression. But it is not as good as the Double Rye. Slighty sweet with a hint of cinnamon.
Taste similar to a single malt, smooth finish. Hints of nuts and Carmel.
A lot of burn for the proof.
Solid. Not too complex. Enjoyable. A little bitter.
A bit boring, but I do like this distiller's flavour profile in general.
Carmel on the nose.  Flat entry, flat in the middle, kinda caramely at the back, very warm finish.  Bitter aftertaste.
One of my go to’s. Never disappoints. Full flavor
Caramel on the nose. Hot for the proof, but overall not too bad.
Hot burn for the proof, finish is insanely quick don’t blink you might miss it, slight sweetness with a little smoke.
2nd taste after it’s opened up...Sweet on the nose. Palate is wood heavy at first and I’m getting some smoke. Then moves to sweet with a quick finish. Confusing.. not really my style.
Woody, spicy, and a little hot coming out the gates.
Nose, Carmel, slt. vanilla, some straw, apricot-peach. Pal; very smooth, clean, soft/sweet.
Smooth, fruity, vanilla and an enjoyable level of spice
As smooth as a Mormon in your neighborhood.
Wow, wasn’t expecting such great flavor.  Smooth, flavorful, oaky, caramel, this is one of the best whiskeys I’ve had.
Nothing special... bourbon spice.  Practically zero finish.
pretty hot for the abv. or just very spicy. buttery and toasted corn more than nutty

this is a solid bourbon for the cost.  
golden straw, vanilla, some fruit and dry grains
spicy front, warm palate
sweet finish some spicy notes linger
Classic, solid and smooth.  Add a drop of water and it comes alive.
I get a lot of the soft fruit on the nose. The fruit is also on the pallet with that bourbon spice. Love this stuff.

Tasty, pretty standard sweet bourbon profile. Some fruit on the palate. 

$8.75USD per pour
BJ’s Brewhouse
First impression is sweet, honey like. With a good burn down. A little bit of bite which is why it’s 4 and not 5 stars
One note.  Smooth, but not overly complex.
About the same as Jack Daniels. 92 proof. Not bad.
